awd_titl_txt: III: Medium: Collaborative Research: Data Mining and Cleaning for Medical Data Warehouse
awd_abstract_narration:
A clinical data warehouse (CDW) is a repository that aggregates medical patient data from many different sources: billing records, electronic medical records including structured data (e.g., codes for diagnoses, procedures, vital signs, etc.), semi-structured reports and free-text dictations. A key benefit of maintaining a CDW lies in its ability to provide the raw data that are needed for large-scale study of real-world health care -- for example, finding a previously unknown association between a pain killer (e.g., Vioxx) and heart disease. Unfortunately, CDWs are riddled with systematic errors that make it difficult to answer even the simplest questions (such as "What fraction of female outpatients have breast cancer?") with any accuracy.

This project focuses on statistical models and learning algorithms for quantifying and correcting errors in CDW records. For example, the project is developing semi-supervised learning methods that use the structured data present in electronic medical records (patient age, weight, medications, billing codes, etc.) in order to quantify the likelihood of error that is associated with the diagnosis codes present in the record (for example, being able to state "There is a 0.2 probability that the correct code was migraine instead of the listed headache"). The project will also develop methods that attempt to control for confounding variables present in the records, in order to remove systematic biases from the data.

These models and learning algorithms will allow CDW users to manage and monitor the uncertainty and error in the data.  This in turn will allow fundamentally new types of analysis to be undertaken, which will result in the discovery of actionable medical knowledge that saves both lives and money.  To make the models and algorithms accessible to medical professionals who may lack computational or statistical background, they will be added to an open-source release of the widely-used I2B2 CDW software.

The project is a collaboration between the Computer Science Department at Rice University and the School of Biomedical informatics at the University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston.  All project results will be made available online (http://www.cs.rice.edu/~cmj4/CDW.htm).

por.por_cntn:
This joint project between the University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston School of Biomedical Informatics (UT-SBMI) and Rice University focused on the aggregation and analysis of large-scale, routinely collected clinical data; i.e., data that are generated in the course of clinical care, rather than a research study or other specific project. Routinely-collected clinical data are potentially useful for many purposes including post-marketing surveillance of drugs, patient-centered outcome research (e.g., is treatment A better than treatment B in the context of a particular disease?) and quality improvement/assurance efforts. However, these data are noisy, subject to non-random biases (e.g., sicker patients get more aggressive treatment that has more severe side effects). Therefore, “making sense” of routinely collected clinical data requires sophisticated computational approaches.

During this NSF-funded three-year grant, extended to four years via no-cost extension, we undertook multiple projects including: 1) maintenance and expansion of the Clinical Data Warehouse (CDW) at UT-SBMI; 2) we began to utilize the CDW to directly improve clinical care via the creation of a Chronic Disease Registry to facilitate population health management; 3) creation, validation and licensing (free of charge) an enterprise Master Person Index (eMPI); 4) clinical data analysis and document/patient classification (“high-throughput phenotyping”); 5) prediction of intra-cranial pressure crises in head-trauma patients; 6) analysis of surgical vital signs to predict long-term outcomes and 7) tracking patients’ surgical paths to predict mortality.

The products of these projects included multiple peer-reviewed journal/conference papers, presentations and other scholarly output, as well as software (e.g., the eMPI mentioned above) licensed free of charge to other academic medical centers and, perhaps most importantly, direct benefit to the health of individual patients via predictive analytics and tools to help clinicians proactively identify patients who require intervention rather than waiting until these patients seek care. We briefly describe one such example.

The Chronic Disease Registry (CDR) is a “Data Mart” extracted daily from the CDW. The CDR contains data on patients who have been diagnosed with one or more of five chronic diseases: hypertension (high blood pressure), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, asthma, diabetes and congestive heart failure. An alert CDR user noted that a particular patient with diabetes had not been seen and had markers of poor control of their diabetes. She contacted the patient, who had not sought care, identified a dangerous complication of diabetes and arranged for the patient to be treated urgently. More details regarding this case can be found at : 

https://med.uth.edu/news/2014/12/04/introducing-the-dsrip-difference/

 

 

 


Last Modified: 06/14/2016
Modified by: Elmer Bernstam
